ground_truth: She carries a copy of the Herald Tribune and still wears her hearing aid as she settles into a folding, canvas deck chair. She gets up, walks to the fence, and looks over, noticing him kneeling down, inspecting his flowers, and touching them affectionately and with some pride. His anger seems to have left him, replaced by the kind of peace that flowers bring many people. He notices her but doesn't speak, and she begins gesturing to him how to take care of his flowers. He listens for a moment, then looks directly at her, showing with the strong movements of his mouth that he objects vigorously to the annoyance of her comments. Started and a little shocked, she moves away from the fence. Jeff is seated in the foreground in a waist shot when the entrance door to his apartment opens behind him. Stella McGaffery comes in, pauses on the landing to watch Jeff. She is a husky, unhandsome, dark-haired woman dressed like a district nurse, with a dark coat, dark felt hat, and a white uniform showing underneath the coat. As she comes down the landing stairs, holding the wrought iron railing with one hand, she carries a small black bag, which she puts down on a table, then takes off her hat and coat and hangs them on a chair. Her attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a fighter than a nurse. Satisfied, she walks to Jeff, whose face shows he doesn't think much of it, and swings the wheelchair around abruptly to face her. She takes the thermometer out of its case, shakes it down, looks at it, and talks as she works. As she leaves him holding the thermometer, the camera pulls back as she crosses to a divan, takes a sheet from underneath, and covers the divan with it, talking all the time. He takes out the thermometer, having no answer, and, defeated, puts it back into his mouth as Stella goes on with her work. The camera pans her over to him as she takes out the thermometer, looks at it, and then gets down the thermometer. She helps him stand on one foot, then helps him off with his pajama top. He hops one step, then she lowers him, face down, on the divan. She gets a bottle of rubbing oil, and the camera is very low at one end of the divan where Jeff's head, half-buried in the sheet, is large in the foreground, while beyond him Stella looms large and powerful-looking.

Her wardrobe is worn and appears as if it belongs more to a pugilist than a nurse. Content, she strides to Jeff, whose visage exhibits he doesn't regard much of it, and twirls the wheelchair around suddenly to face her. She extracts the thermometer from its container, shakes it down, observes it, and converses as she operates. As she departs him gripping the thermometer, the camera withdraws as she crosses to a couch, extracts a sheet from underneath, and covers the couch with it, speaking continually. She fetches a container of rubbing oil, and the camera is very low at one extremity of the couch where Jeff's head, half-submerged in the sheet, is large in the foreground, while beyond him Stella looms large and powerful-looking.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: She holds a Herald Tribune and keeps her hearing aid in while settling into a folding canvas deck chair. She approaches the fence and sees him kneeling, inspecting his flowers with pride and affection, his anger seemingly replaced by peace. She gestures advice on caring for the flowers, but he vigorously objects with strong mouth movements, leaving her startled. In the foreground, Jeff sits as the apartment door opens, and Stella McGaffery enters. Husky and unhandsome, dressed like a district nurse with a dark coat, hat, and white uniform, she descends the landing, puts her black bag on a table, and hangs up her coat and hat, appearing more fighter than nurse. Satisfied, she approaches Jeff, swings his wheelchair to face her, and talks while shaking a thermometer. She leaves him holding it, crosses to a divan, and covers it with a sheet, speaking all the while. Defeated, he puts the thermometer back in his mouth. She helps him stand on one foot and removes his pajama top, lowers him face-down on the divan, and fetches rubbing oil. The camera captures Jeff's head, half-buried in the sheet, in the foreground, while Stella looms powerfully in the background.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: She holds a Herald Tribune and her hearing aid, sitting in a folding canvas chair. She approaches the fence, observing a man tending to his flowers. He appears peaceful rather than angry, notices her but stays silent. She gestures flower care tips, but he responds vigorously against her advice, startling her away. In the foreground, Jeff is seated as Stella McGaffery enters, watching him. Stella, a dark-haired, husky woman dressed like a district nurse, pauses on the landing. She carries a black bag, places it on a table, and hangs her worn coat and hat—a fighter’s attire—on a chair. Unimpressed, Jeff swings his wheelchair to face her. Stella takes out, shakes down, and checks a thermometer, talking as she works. Leaving Jeff holding the thermometer, she covers a divan with a sheet. He replaces the thermometer without a response. Stella helps him stand, removes his pajama top, then lowers him onto the divan. She retrieves a bottle of rubbing oil. The camera captures Jeff's large foreground head, half-buried in the sheet, and Stella, looming powerfully beyond him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
She holds a copy of the esteemed Herald Tribune in her hands and continues to wear her hearing aid as she comfortably settles herself into a folding, canvas deck chair. After some time, she rises from her seat, walks over to the nearby fence, and peers over it. Her gaze falls upon him as he kneels down to meticulously inspect his flowers, touching them with an affectionate and prideful demeanor. It seems that any anger or frustration he might have been feeling has dissipated, replaced by the tranquility and solace that many people find in tending to their flowers. He notices her presence there but chooses not to acknowledge her with words. Instead, she begins to gesture to him, attempting to communicate instructions on how best to care for his cherished flowers. He listens to her for a brief moment before looking directly at her, expressing his strong objections through the exaggerated movements of his mouth, clearly indicating his displeasure at the intrusion of her remarks. Startled and somewhat taken aback by his reaction, she steps away from the fence.

In the foreground, Jeff is seated in his wheelchair, captured in a waist shot, when suddenly, the door to his apartment opens quietly behind him. Stella McGaffery makes her entrance, pausing momentarily on the landing to observe Jeff. Stella is a robust, unhandsome woman with dark hair, dressed in the fashion of a district nurse, wearing a dark coat, a matching dark felt hat, and a white uniform that peeks out from beneath her coat. As she descends the landing stairs, grasping the wrought iron railing with one hand for balance, she carries a small, black bag. Upon reaching the table, she places the bag down, removes her hat and coat, and carefully hangs them on a chair. Her attire appears to be well-worn, suggesting it belongs more to a fighter than to a nurse. Once satisfied with her tasks, she approaches Jeff, whose facial expression indicates his lack of appreciation for her presence. She abruptly spins his wheelchair around to face her directly. With efficiency, she takes the thermometer out of its case, gives it a brisk shake down, examines it, and starts talking as she continues her work. She leaves him holding the thermometer in his mouth and, as the camera pulls back, she crosses over to a nearby divan. She takes a sheet from underneath it and spreads it over the divan, all the while maintaining her flow of conversation. Left with no response, he eventually removes the thermometer from his mouth, feeling defeated, and places it back in as Stella carries on with her duties. The camera tracks her movement over to him as she takes the thermometer from him, inspects it, and then sets it down. She assists him in standing on one foot, helping him remove his pajama top with care. He makes a small hop, and then she gently lowers him, face down, onto the divan. She retrieves a bottle of rubbing oil, and the camera angle shifts to a low position at one end of the divan, where Jeff’s head is half-buried in the sheet and appears prominent in the foreground. Meanwhile, beyond him, Stella stands large and formidable, her presence looming over him as she prepares to attend to him with the oil.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
With a copy of the esteemed Herald Tribune held firmly in her hands, she continues to keep her hearing aid securely in place as she relaxes into the comfort of a folding, canvas deck chair. After a short while, she gradually rises from her comfortable seat, making her way over to the nearby fence, where she leans over to get a better view. Her gaze lands on him as he is kneeling down, intently inspecting his flowers with meticulous care, gently touching them with an affectionate and prideful demeanor. It appears that any anger or frustration that he might have been experiencing earlier has now completely dissipated, replaced by the tranquility and solace that many individuals discover in the act of tending to their beloved flowers. He is aware of her presence nearby but opts to refrain from acknowledging her verbally. Instead, she begins to gesture emphatically at him, attempting to communicate instructions regarding the best methods for caring for his cherished flowers. He listens attentively to her for a brief moment but then turns to look directly at her, conveying his strong objections through exaggerated movements of his mouth, clearly indicating his displeasure at the intrusion of her unsolicited advice. Startled and somewhat taken aback by his vehement reaction, she retreats from the fence.

Meanwhile, in the foreground, Jeff is seated resolutely in his wheelchair, captured in a waist shot, when suddenly and quietly, the door to his apartment opens behind him without warning. Stella McGaffery makes her entrance with a confident stride, pausing momentarily on the landing to observe Jeff. Stella is a robust woman, not conventionally handsome, with dark hair. She is dressed in the fashion typical of a district nurse, donning a dark coat and a matching dark felt hat, with her white uniform peeking out from beneath her coat. As she descends the landing stairs, she grasps the wrought iron railing with one hand for balance while she carries a small, black bag in her other hand. Upon reaching the table, she places down her bag, removes her hat and coat with deliberate care, and carefully hangs them over a chair. Her attire seems well-worn, suggesting it is more fitting for a fighter than for a nurse. Once satisfied with her tasks, she approaches Jeff, whose facial expression clearly indicates his lack of appreciation for her presence. Without hesitation, she spins his wheelchair around with an abrupt motion so that he faces her directly. With efficiency and precision, she takes the thermometer out of its case, gives it a brisk shake down, examines it thoroughly, and begins talking as she continues her work. She leaves Jeff holding the thermometer in his mouth, and as the camera pulls back, she crosses over to a nearby divan. She retrieves a sheet from underneath it and skillfully spreads it over the divan, all while continuing her steady flow of conversation. Left without a response, Jeff eventually removes the thermometer from his mouth in a gesture of defeat and then places it back in as Stella carries on with her duties unperturbed. The camera tracks her movement as she approaches him, takes the thermometer from him, inspects it once more, and then sets it down carefully. She assists Jeff in standing up on one foot with care, helping him remove his pajama top gently. He makes a small hop before she lowers him carefully, face down, onto the divan. Retrieving a bottle of rubbing oil, the camera angle shifts to a low position at one end of the divan, capturing Jeff’s head half-buried in the sheet, prominent in the foreground. Meanwhile, beyond him, Stella stands large and formidable, her presence looming over him as she prepares to attend to him with the oil.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: She clutches a copy of the Herald Tribune in one hand while the other remains occupied with adjusting her hearing aid, ensuring it fits comfortably as she settles into a folding, canvas deck chair. After a moment of adjustment in her chair, she rises and takes deliberate steps towards the fence. Peering over, she observes him kneeling down among his garden flowers, carefully examining each bloom, and tenderly touching them with a sense of pride and affection that seems to have replaced any previous traces of anger with the tranquility often brought by nature. Though he notices her presence, he maintains his silence, prompting her to begin a series of gestures aimed at instructing him on the nuances of flower care. He initially listens, his focus momentarily captured, but soon meets her gaze directly, responding with exaggerated lip movements that convey his strong objections to her unsolicited advice. Surprised and somewhat taken aback by his forceful reaction, she steps away from the fence, slightly startled. As the scene shifts, Jeff is shown seated in the foreground, captured in a waist shot, his attention momentarily redirected when the entrance door to his apartment swings open behind him. Stella McGaffery enters, halting briefly on the landing to observe Jeff, her husky frame and unhandsomely dark-haired appearance complemented by her attire—reminiscent of a district nurse—with a dark coat, a dark felt hat, and a pristine white uniform peeking through the layers. She descends the landing stairs with calculated steps, gripping the wrought iron railing securely in one hand while the other carries a small black bag, which she places on a table before shedding her hat and coat. She hangs them over a chair, the garments’ worn and battle-ready look, more befitting a fighter than a nurse, contrasting with her professional uniform. With everything in place, she approaches Jeff, who appears unimpressed, and swiftly swings his wheelchair to face her directly. Proceeding with her routine, she retrieves a thermometer from its case, swiftly shakes it down, and gives it a cursory glance while engaging in conversation. Leaving him with the thermometer in his mouth, she moves to a divan across the room, pulling a sheet from beneath it, and spreads it out with non-stop chatter. As he extracts the thermometer, lacking any retort, he returns it to his mouth, surrendering to the situation while Stella continues with her tasks. The camera follows her closely as she returns, removes the thermometer once again, examines it, and puts it away before assisting him to stand on one foot. Her assistance extends to helping him remove his pajama top as he hops a step, allowing her to gently lower him face down onto the divan. She then retrieves a bottle of rubbing oil, with the camera angle positioned low at the divan's edge, creating a vivid contrast between Jeff’s head, half-buried in the sheet and looming large in the foreground, and Stella's robust figure dominating the background, poised to begin her remedial work.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: She settles into a folding canvas deck chair with her Herald Tribune and hearing aid, but soon rises to the fence to observe him tending to his flowers with affection and pride, indicating a newfound peace. Noticing her, he listens briefly as she gestures instructions on flower care, but expresses his strong objection to her comments, prompting her to step back, startled. Meanwhile, Jeff sits in the foreground as Stella McGaffery enters the apartment, pausing to watch him before descending the landing stairs. Dressed like a district nurse in a dark coat, hat, and white uniform, she places her black bag on a table, removes her hat and coat, and hangs them on a chair, her attire suggesting a fighter's resilience. Stella approaches Jeff, swinging his wheelchair to face her, and begins her work routine: shaking down the thermometer, handing it to Jeff, and talking as she moves. While he holds the thermometer, she prepares the divan and converses continuously. After he returns the thermometer, she assists him, helping him stand on one foot, removing his pajama top, and guiding him face down onto the divan. She retrieves a bottle of rubbing oil, positioning herself powerfully over Jeff's half-buried head as she proceeds with her duties.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description:
She carries a copy of the Herald Tribune, an international newspaper known for its comprehensive coverage of global affairs, and still wears her hearing aid, a reminder of her struggle with hearing loss, as she settles into a folding, canvas deck chair. She gets up, walks to the fence of the quaint neighborhood garden, and looks over, noticing him kneeling down, inspecting his flowers, and touching them affectionately and with some pride. His anger seems to have left him, replaced by the kind of peace that flowers, often symbolizing renewal and tranquility, bring many people. He notices her but doesn't speak, and she begins gesturing to him how to take care of his flowers, perhaps sharing knowledge passed down from her time as a devoted gardener. He listens for a moment, then looks directly at her, showing with the strong movements of his mouth that he objects vigorously to the annoyance of her comments. Startled and a little shocked by his reaction, she moves away from the fence.

Jeff is seated in the foreground in a waist shot when the entrance door to his New York apartment opens behind him. Stella McGaffery comes in, pauses on the landing to watch Jeff, who is confined to a wheelchair due to a recent accident that has left him temporarily disabled. She is a husky, unhandsome, dark-haired woman dressed like a district nurse, frequently attending to patients in urban areas, with a dark coat, dark felt hat, and a white uniform showing underneath the coat. As she comes down the landing stairs, holding the wrought iron railing with one hand, she carries a small black bag, quintessential of healthcare workers who make house calls, which she puts down on a table, then takes off her hat and coat and hangs them on a chair. Her attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a fighter than a nurse, suggesting a life of resilience and heavy labor. Satisfied, she walks to Jeff, whose face shows he doesn't think much of it, and swings the wheelchair around abruptly to face her. She takes the thermometer, a classic mercury device, out of its case, shakes it down with the expertise of a seasoned nurse, looks at it, and talks as she works. As she leaves him holding the thermometer, the camera pulls back as she crosses to a divan, takes a sheet from underneath, and covers the divan with it, talking all the time, illustrating her multitasking abilities. He takes out the thermometer, having no answer, and, defeated, puts it back into his mouth as Stella goes on with her work.

The camera pans her over to him as she takes out the thermometer, looks at it, and then gets down to note the reading. She helps him stand on one foot, a challenging task given his current condition, then helps him off with his pajama top. He hops one step, then she lowers him, face down, on the divan. She gets a bottle of rubbing oil, known for its soothing properties, and the camera is very low at one end of the divan where Jeff's head, half-buried in the sheet, is large in the foreground, while beyond him Stella looms large and powerful-looking.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. Her attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a fighter than a nurse. Satisfied she walks to Jeff whose face shows he does not think much of it and swings the wheelchair around abruptly to face her. She takes the thermometer out of its case shakes it down looks at it and talks as she works. As she leaves him holding the thermometer the camera pulls back as she crosses to a divan takes a sheet from underneath and covers the divan with it talking all the time. He takes out the thermometer having no answer and defeated puts it back into his mouth as Stella goes on with her work. The camera pans her over to him as she takes out the thermometer looks at it and then gets down the thermometer. She helps him stand on one foot then helps him off with his pajama top. He hops one step then she lowers him face down on the divan. She gets a bottle of rubbing oil and the camera is very low at one end of the divan where Jeff's head halfburied in the sheet is large in the foreground while beyond him. Stella looms large and powerfullooking.

test_cases.description: She carries a copy of the Herald Tribune and still wears her hearing aid as she settles into a folding canvas deck chair. She gets up walks to the fence and looks over noticing him kneeling down inspecting his flowers and touching them affectionately and with some pride. His anger seems to have left him replaced by the kind of peace that flowers bring many people. He notices her but does not speak and she begins gesturing to him how to take care of his flowers. He listens for a moment then looks directly at her showing with the strong movements of his mouth that he objects vigorously to the annoyance of her comments. The camera pans her over to him as she takes out the thermometer looks at it and then gets down the thermometer. She helps him stand on one foot then helps him off with his pajama top. test_cases.description: She carries a copy of the Herald Tribune and still wears her hearing aid as she settles into a folding canvas deck chair. She gets up walks to the fence and looks over noticing him kneeling down inspecting his flowers and touching them affectionately and with some pride. She gets a bottle of rubbing oil and the camera is very low at one end of the divan where Jeff's head halfburied in the sheet is large in the foreground while beyond him. Stella looms large and powerfullooking.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The dog carries a copy of the Herald Tribune and still wears her hearing aid as the dog settles into a folding, canvas deck chair. The dog gets up, walks to the fence, and looks over, noticing the bird kneeling down, inspecting its flowers, and touching them affectionately and with some pride. The bird's anger seems to have left it, replaced by the kind of peace that flowers bring many people. The bird notices the dog but doesn't speak, and the dog begins gesturing to the bird how to take care of its flowers. The bird listens for a moment, then looks directly at the dog, showing with the strong movements of its mouth that it objects vigorously to the annoyance of the dog's comments. Started and a little shocked, the dog moves away from the fence. The fish is seated in the foreground in a waist shot when the entrance door to its apartment opens behind it. The tree comes in, pauses on the landing to watch the fish. The tree is a husky, unhandsome, dark-haired figure dressed like a district nurse, with a dark coat, dark felt hat, and a white uniform showing underneath the coat. As the tree comes down the landing stairs, holding the wrought iron railing with one hand, the tree carries a small black bag, which it puts down on a table, then takes off its hat and coat and hangs them on a chair. The tree's attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a fighter than a nurse. Satisfied, the tree walks to the fish, whose face shows it doesn't think much of it, and swings the wheelchair around abruptly to face the tree. The tree takes the thermometer out of its case, shakes it down, looks at it, and talks as it works. As the tree leaves the fish holding the thermometer, the camera pulls back as the tree crosses to a divan, takes a sheet from underneath, and covers the divan with it, talking all the time. The fish takes out the thermometer, having no answer, and, defeated, puts it back into its mouth as the tree goes on with its work. The camera pans the tree over to the fish as the tree takes out the thermometer, looks at it, and then gets down the thermometer. The tree helps the fish stand on one foot, then helps the fish off with its pajama top. The fish hops one step, then the tree lowers it, face down, on the divan. The tree gets a bottle of rubbing oil, and the camera is very low at one end of the divan where the fish's head, half-buried in the sheet, is large in the foreground, while beyond it the tree looms large and powerful-looking.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She carries a copy of the Evening Gazette and still wears her eyeglasses as she settles into a wooden, wicker picnic chair. She gets up, walks to the hedge, and looks over, noticing him kneeling down, inspecting his vegetables, and touching them affectionately and with some pride. His frustration seems to have left him, replaced by the kind of peace that vegetables bring many people. He notices her but doesn't speak, and she begins gesturing to him how to take care of his vegetables. He listens for a moment, then looks directly at her, showing with the strong movements of his mouth that he objects vigorously to the annoyance of her advice. Startled and a little shocked, she moves away from the hedge. Jeff is seated in the foreground in a torso shot when the entrance door to his condo opens behind him. Stella McGaffery comes in, pauses on the landing to watch Jeff. She is a husky, unhandsome, dark-haired woman dressed like a district nurse, with a dark jacket, dark beret, and a white apron showing underneath the jacket. As she comes down the landing stairs, holding the wooden banister with one hand, she carries a small brown satchel, which she puts down on a stool, then takes off her beret and jacket and hangs them on a rack. Her attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a lumberjack than a nurse. Satisfied, she walks to Jeff, whose face shows he doesn't think much of it, and swings the armchair around abruptly to face her. She takes the stethoscope out of its case, shakes it down, looks at it, and talks as she works. As she leaves him holding the stethoscope, the camera pulls back as she crosses to a couch, takes a blanket from underneath, and covers the couch with it, talking all the time. He takes out the stethoscope, having no answer, and, defeated, puts it back into his ears as Stella goes on with her work. The camera pans her over to him as she takes out the stethoscope, looks at it, and then gets down the stethoscope. She helps him stand on one foot, then helps him off with his robe. He hops one step, then she lowers him, face down, on the couch. She gets a bottle of lotion, and the camera is very low at one end of the couch where Jeff's head, half-buried in the blanket, is large in the foreground, while beyond him Stella looms large and powerful-looking.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She drops a copy of the Herald Tribune and still adjusts her hearing aid as she reclines into a folding, canvas deck chair. She sits down, runs to the fence, and peers over, noticing him jumping up, counting his flowers, and waving at them affectionately and with some pride. His anger seems to have vanished, substituted by the kind of peace that flowers remind many people of. He observes her but doesn't speak, and she begins miming to him how to ignore his flowers. He ignores for a moment, then turns directly to her, showing with the strong movements of his mouth that he agrees vigorously to the curiosity of her comments. Surprised and a little amused, she retreats from the fence. Jeff is reclining in the foreground in a waist shot when the entrance door to his apartment creaks behind him. Stella McGaffery shuffles in, pauses on the landing to observe Jeff. She is a husky, unhandsome, dark-haired woman dressed like a district nurse, with a dark coat, dark felt hat, and a white uniform peeking underneath the coat. As she glides down the landing stairs, gripping the wrought iron railing with one hand, she drops a small black bag, which she kicks under a table, then takes off her hat and coat and tosses them on a chair. Her attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a warrior than a nurse. Contented, she strides to Jeff, whose face shows he doesn't care much for it, and rotates the wheelchair around deliberately to face her. She extracts the thermometer out of its case, flicks it up, scrutinizes it, and sings as she works. As she leaves him juggling the thermometer, the camera zooms out as she leaps to a divan, pulls a blanket from underneath, and drapes the divan with it, singing all the time. He removes the thermometer, having no response, and, resigned, places it back into his mouth as Stella continues with her work. The camera follows her over to him as she retrieves the thermometer, observes it, and then tucks down the thermometer. She assists him in balancing on one foot, then helps him take off his pajama top. He skips one step, then she places him, face down, on the divan. She grabs a bottle of rubbing oil, and the camera is very low at one end of the divan where Jeff's head, half-hidden in the sheet, is magnified in the foreground, while beyond him Stella looms large and strong-looking.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The grapefruit carries a blueprint of the Galactic Manifest and still wears its monocle as it settles into a porcelain, velvet ottoman. The grapefruit gets up, walks to the hammock, and looks over, noticing the satellite kneeling down, inspecting its marionettes, and touching them affectionately and with some pride. The satellite's bewilderment seems to have left it, replaced by the kind of tranquility that marionettes bring many creatures. The satellite notices the grapefruit but doesn't speak, and the grapefruit begins gesturing to it how to take care of its marionettes. The satellite listens for a moment, then looks directly at the grapefruit, showing with the strong movements of its whiskers that it objects vigorously to the irritation of its comments. Startled and a little shocked, the grapefruit moves away from the hammock. The treadmill is seated in the foreground in a waist shot when the hatchway to its igloo opens behind it. The comet McGaffery comes in, pauses on the landing to watch the treadmill. It is a wispy, unhandsome, azure-tailed creature dressed like a safari guide, with a plaid scarf, plaid felt helmet, and a pearl jumpsuit showing underneath the scarf. As it comes down the landing stairs, holding the avant-garde railing with one hand, it carries a giant obsidian egg, which it puts down on a piano, then takes off its helmet and scarf and hangs them on a telescope. Its attire is worn and looks as if it belongs more to a gladiator than a guide. Satisfied, it walks to the treadmill, whose face shows it doesn't think much of it, and swings the easel around abruptly to face it. It takes the kaleidoscope out of its case, shakes it down, looks at it, and talks as it works. As it leaves the treadmill holding the kaleidoscope, the camera pulls back as it crosses to a bicycle, takes a map from underneath, and covers the bicycle with it, talking all the time. The treadmill takes out the kaleidoscope, having no answer, and, defeated, puts it back into its mouth as the comet goes on with its work. The camera pans it over to the treadmill as it takes out the kaleidoscope, looks at it, and then gets down the kaleidoscope. It helps the treadmill stand on one wheel, then helps it off with its saddle. The treadmill hops one step, then it lowers it, face down, on the bicycle. It gets a bottle of varnish, and the camera is very low at one end of the bicycle where the treadmill's nose, half-buried in the map, is large in the foreground, while beyond it, the comet looms large and powerful-looking.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The squirrel hops through the air holding a copy of the Daily Gazette and still balances her monocle as she tumbles into a reclining, plastic lawn chair. She leaps up, skips to the barn, and peeks over, observing him crouching down, examining his vegetables, and poking them cautiously and with some uncertainty. His confusion seems to have drifted away, replaced by the sort of calm that vegetables bring many creatures. He spies her but doesn't sing, and she starts dancing at him how to prune his vegetables. He observes for a moment, then gazes directly at her, conveying with the exaggerated movements of his ears that he agrees intensely to the disturbance of her miming. Alarmed and a little amazed, she rolls away from the barn. Kevin is bouncing in the foreground in a waist shot when the trapdoor to his attic opens beneath him. Emma McPringle strides in, pauses on the ceiling to eye Kevin. She is a slight, unattractive, fair-haired woman clothed like a park ranger, with a light jacket, light straw hat, and a green scarf peeking under the jacket. As she descends to the ceiling ladder, clutching the wooden beam with one foot, she swings a large red suitcase, which she places beside a counter, then pulls off her hat and jacket and drapes them on a rail. Her appearance is ragged and looks as if it belongs more to a boxer than a ranger. Content, she dances to Kevin, whose face signals he doesn't admire it much, and spins the rocking chair abruptly to face her. She pulls the stethoscope out of its box, twists it upward, peers at it, and sings as she dances. As she leaves him juggling the stethoscope, the camera zooms back as she tiptoes to a hammock, pulls a quilt from under, and wraps the hammock with it, singing all the while. He removes the stethoscope, having no tune, and, defeated, slips it back into his pocket as Emma carries on with her dance. The camera follows her over to him as she pulls out the stethoscope, examines it, and then topples the stethoscope. She assists him roll onto one knee, then aids him off with his shirt. He spins one turn, then she lowers him, face sideways, on the hammock. She fetches a jar of massage cream, and the camera is very high at one side of the hammock where Kevin's feet, half-wrapped in the quilt, appear large in the background, while beyond him Emma looms small and fragile-looking.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She juggles a loaf of sourdough bread and still sports her monocle as she reclines into a wicker, velvet sofa. She rises, skips to the hedge, and peeks over, noticing him sitting down, contemplating his pebbles, and tapping them analytically and with some curiosity. His frustration seems to have vanished, replaced by the sense of wonder that stones bring many individuals. He observes her but doesn't converse, and she begins signaling to him how to arrange his stones. He ponders briefly, then gazes directly at her, demonstrating with exaggerated facial expressions that he objects fervently to the irritation of her gestures. Surprised and a bit taken aback, she retreats from the hedge. Jeff is lounging in the foreground in a medium shot when the exit door to his flat swings open behind him. Stella McGaffery enters, hesitates on the platform to observe Jeff. She is a sturdy, unconventional, light-haired woman dressed like a postal worker, with a beige jacket, green beret, and a checkered blouse visible beneath the jacket. As she descends the platform steps, gripping the wooden banister with one hand, she balances a large yellow backpack, which she places on a bench, then removes her beret and jacket and drapes them over a sofa. Her outfit is rugged and seems more fitting for an explorer than a postal worker. Contented, she strides to Jeff, whose expression reveals his skepticism of the attire, and spins the armchair around swiftly to face her. She retrieves the stethoscope from its box, twirls it around, examines it, and chats as she maneuvers. As she leaves him holding the stethoscope, the view zooms out as she strolls to a hammock, retrieves a quilt from beneath, and drapes the hammock with it, chattering continuously. He fiddles with the stethoscope, having no retort, and, resigned, places it back around his neck as Stella continues her task. The camera tracks her over to him as she removes the stethoscope, observes it, and then hangs the stethoscope. She assists him in balancing on one leg, then helps him shed his robe. He bounces one step, then she eases him, face-first, onto the hammock. She fetches a jar of massage cream, and the camera is very low at one edge of the hammock where Jeff's head, partially enveloped in the quilt, is prominent in the foreground, while beyond him, Stella appears imposing and formidable.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The zebra totes a copy of the Daily Gazette and still dons her monocle as she nestles into a rigid, metal beanbag. She stands up, prances to the hedge, and peers beyond, observing the cat squatting down, examining his pebbles, and patting them lovingly and with some amusement. His fury seems to have abandoned him, replaced by the sort of tranquility that pebbles grant many creatures. He spots her but remains silent, and she commences signaling to him how to nurture his pebbles. He heeds briefly, then glances directly at her, demonstrating with the vigorous twitches of his snout that he protests strongly against the irritation of her signals. Alarmed and a bit startled, she backs away from the hedge. Gus is perched in the backdrop in a full-length shot when the gateway door to his cottage creaks open behind him. Delia McGaffery strolls in, hesitates on the veranda to observe Gus. She is a lean, charming, light-haired man dressed like a ballroom dancer, with a pale scarf, bright cap, and a colorful outfit peeking beneath the scarf. As she strolls down the veranda steps, gripping the wooden banister with one paw, she bears a large blue basket, which she places down on a shelf, then removes her cap and scarf and hangs them on a hook. Her garb is aged and appears as if it belongs more to a gymnast than a dancer. Content, she strolls to Gus, whose grin indicates he isn't impressed by it, and twirls the rocking chair sharply to face her. She extracts the compass from its pouch, flips it open, examines it, and converses as she proceeds. As she leaves him clutching the compass, the spotlight zooms out as she strides to a hammock, extracts a pillow from below, and drapes the hammock with it, chattering continuously. He retracts the compass, devoid of retort, and, resigned, places it back between his teeth as Delia continues with her tasks. The lens trails her over to him as she extracts the compass, inspects it, and then stows away the compass. She aids him in balancing on one paw, then assists him in removing his nightshirt. He skips one pace, then she lowers him, belly down, on the hammock. She fetches a flask of fragrant balm, and the camera is very close at one end of the hammock where Gus's head, partially buried in the pillow, is prominent in the foreground, while beyond him Delia towers large and formidable.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: She settles into a canvas deck chair, still wearing her hearing aid and holding a copy of the Herald Tribune. She notices a man tending his flowers with peace, contrasting his earlier anger. She gestures advice, but he objects strongly, prompting her to retreat. In the foreground, Jeff sits as Stella McGaffery enters. A robust, plain-looking woman, Stella is dressed like a district nurse. She sets down her black bag, removes her coat and hat, and tends to Jeff, whose reaction to her presence is indifferent. Stella shakes down a thermometer, gives it to Jeff, and covers a divan with a sheet, talking continuously. Jeff, unable to respond, places the thermometer in his mouth. Stella assists him onto one foot and off with his pajama top, then onto the divan. She applies rubbing oil, the camera capturing Jeff's head in the foreground while Stella appears large and commanding in the background.
